citation.article-title: Legionella tucsonensis sp. nov. isolated from a renal transplant recipient.

p.s: Description of Legionella tucsonensis sp. nov.
Legionella tucsonensis (tuc.so.nen'sis N. L. fem. adj. tucsonensis, coming from Tucson, Ariz.)
Legionella tucsonensis is a gram-negative rod with a single polar lagellum.
Its cellular fatty acids are predominantly branch chained.
It is positive in reactions for catalase, gelatinase, and Î²-lactamase and requires cysteine for growth.
It is negative in reactions for urease, reduction of nitrate to nitrite, oxidase, hydrolysis of hippurate, and acid production from D-glucose.
It can be identified serologically in the slide agglutination test with absorbed antiserum.
The type strain of L. tucsoneisis is 1087-AZ-H (ATCC 49180), which has a G+C content of 44 mol%.
It was isolated from human pleural fluid.
